title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: I have an 820-3536-a macbook pro retina, I get an amber light on the charger, but the computer wont turn on, I am missing pp5v_s4, pp5v_s5 is presant. board was water damaged, thanks for any help

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message:
Check if pp5v_s4 is pulsing, you may need an oscilloscope, pulses are pretty fast and DMM may not catch it....

Also check for water damage around U6100 and U1900...

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: as far as i can tell pp5v_s4 isnt pulsing, but i dont have an oscilloscope. there was some blue along the 1-4 pin side of U1900 and the ground pin of U6100 had some aswell

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: check the traces between the resistors around U6100 and the CPU

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: The only area that seems to have bad traces are the probe points on the pins 1-4 side of u8330

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Look up all the termination resistors in the data lines of U6100 and check them all. Also check continuity between them all. I think there are 16 of them.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: the only resistor that i found that was not what the schematic said was r6131, resistance was 77k ohms but theres no resistor on the board there; and its also not labled "no stuff"

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Voltage on PPVRTC?

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: I am getting 274 mv on ppvrtc_g3h

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Yeah, there is your problem. Check around U1900, usually corroded pins or dead. Also check resistance to GND on PPVRTC rail.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: U1900 had pins 1-4 pretty corroded, pin 1 definiately the worst of them, getting anywhere from 3-8 ohms resistance to ground on ppvrtc

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: 3-8 Ohms with U1900 removed? Is way too low of course, should be in the Ks.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: I took u1900 off the board and got 2 ohms resistance to ground :/

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message:
Most likely bad CPU and this is junk.

Sometimes it is a short that can be worked around, such as in this case: fast forward to 1:30:00 to see me fix a case of 0 ohms to ground on a board with shorted PPVRTC_G3H that is very similar to yours. 

[url]https://youtu.be/RtHRwZxvjME?t=5434[/url]

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: There is a few caps on the PPVRTC line to GND. Take them all off, if there still is a short the CPU is dead.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: took off c1910 resistance to ground is now around 30m ohms

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: okay i replaced c1910 and u1900 i now get 3.35 volts on ppvrtc_g3h board still doesnt power on; also still missing s4 power rails

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Check carefully for power cycling on the 5V bus L7520. PPBUS present at 12.6V? 3V at L7560?

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: ppbus is at 12.6v theres 3.34v at l7560 if theres 5v cycling at l7520 my meter just reads a steady 0

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Check if U1900 is putting out 32kHz RTC signal.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: pin 12 is putting out 32.77khz

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Check with the scope on L7520 if there is power pulses. Multimeter may be too slow to catch it.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: is there any way i can check without an oscilloscope? i dont have one

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Uhm, how do you know the 32kHz then? Most multimeters will get the short burst, but the auto ranging ones usually don't, is yours auto ranging?

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: I used the frequency setting on my multi meter and thats what it said; it is auto ranging

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: I do have a multi meter without auto ranging, ill try to find it

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: I still get a flat 0

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Voltage on C1300/03? ADAPTER_EN, DSW_PWRGD?

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: 3.35v on c1300 and C1303, 3.39v on adapter_en; and 3.42v on dsw_pwrgd

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Well, I'm running out out ideas here. If there is no short on L7520 to GND it should power up and pulse at least. Could be corrosion under SMC or a dead CPU at this point.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: how is pp5v_s4 created?

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: From the CPU/PCH in combo with SMC.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: so the boards probably toast then, there wasnt any corrosion around the smc but there was some close to the cpu, Im guessing its probably toast, there was no short to ground on L7560

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: I'm out of ideas really. Inspect closely for corrosion, that is about all there is left to do. Reflow SMC/CPU if you are really desperate.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: any specific lines i should be looking for corrosion on? other than pp5v_s4?

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Anything around CPU/SMC/U6100/clock

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: If U6100 died could that leave me with no pp5v_s4? Because i know U6100 was corroded a little when i first opened it up

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: I doubt the chip is dead. Usually the traces or resistors are corroded. Yes without a functioning U6100 the board will power cycle. Pull U6100 and read it on the programmer, do not loose the original dump!

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: R6131 gives me 89.7k ohms and is supposed to be 33

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: theres nothing on the board there but its not labled no stuff on the schematic

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: R6131 is no stuff on these boards.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: okay i replaced U1900 with a brand new chip and now L7520 seems to be pulsing: still no fan spin

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: pp5v_s0 is pulsing

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Anything can cause pulsing power. Is CPU Vcore pulsing too. The usual suspects apply, U6100 are, termination resistors, U1950.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: yes PPVCC_S0_CPU is pulsing

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: U6100 area issue is most likely then. Could also be pretty much anything else. Check all termination resistors in U6100 data lines and all traces between them.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: r6130 isnt no stuff is it?

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: That is correct.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: okay that resistor is missing on my board not sure if i knocked it off messing with u6100 or what ill replace and see what happens

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: I meant it IS no stuff.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: i was getting an infinite resistance from pin 1 to 2, so if i put a 33 ohm resistor there would that work?

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Again, R6130 is not supposed to be on the board.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: so its not apart of that system at all?

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: I don't know what you want me to say man......NO STUFF.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: I dont have a programmer, would it be worth it for me to get a new U6100 chip or is that not going to be it, I havent found any problems with any of the resistors and they all seem to be connected

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: To fix the board you will need a programmer, assuming it is U6100. Get an identical donor board and take U6100, but only for testing as the ME region needs to be fixed if swapping the chip worked.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: so buying a pre programmed U6100 wont work? also how much can i expect to pay for a programmer

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Buy a TL866. Pre programmed usually is a dump from another board and ME region will be fucked. Get a donor board, you need those anyway.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: sorry for being an idiot but whats the "me" region

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: Please google "ME region" way too complicated to explain here, but it is important to save the original one to merge with a new BIOS.

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: put the new bios chip on, still power cycling resistors to U6100 still seem good, anything else i can look for? or dead cpu?

title: 820-3536-a wont turn on
message: I'm out of ideas on this one.
